newsitem.title: UK: UK petrol price war cost BP $140 mln in 1996.
newsitem.headline: UK petrol price war cost BP $140 mln in 1996.

text.p: A ferocious price war in the U.K. gasoline market cost British Petroleum (BP) $140 million in 1996, the company said on Tuesday.
"The net impact of the price battles in the U.K. on the bottom line was $140 million," BP chief executive John Browne told reporters.
BP earlier reported a big jump in its next replacement cost profit for calendar 1996, which climbed by nearly a third to a record 2.62 billion stg.

BP Oil chief executive Rolf Stomberg said there were signs the price war was beginning to subside with retail margins finding a degree of equilibrium, albeit it at a lower level than before Esso launched its Price Watch campain in 1995.
"The picture began to get better starting in the third quarter. We are trading profitably now," Stomberg told reporters.
